original.title: Book VIII: The Decline of States
original.preview: Socrates: And so, Glaucon, we have arrived at the conclusion that in the perfect State wives and children are to be in common.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And so, Glaucon, we have arrived at the conclusion that in the perfect State wives and children are to be in common; and that all education and the pursuits of war and peace are also to be common, and the best philosophers and the bravest warriors are to be their kings.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: That has been acknowledged.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Yes, and we have further acknowledged that the governors will take their soldiers and place them in houses which are common to all, and contain nothing private.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Yes, I remember that no one was to have any of the ordinary possessions of mankind; they were to be warrior athletes and guardians, receiving from the other citizens only their maintenance.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: True. And now that this division of our task is concluded, let us find the point at which we digressed, that we may return into the old path.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: There is no difficulty in returning; you implied that you had finished the description of the State. You said that such a State was good, and that the man was good who answered to it.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: And you said further that if this was the true form, then the others were false; and of the false forms, you said there were four principal ones, and that their defects were worth examining.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Your recollection is most exact.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: I shall particularly wish to hear what were the four constitutions of which you were speaking.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: That question is easily answered: the four governments of which I spoke, so far as they have distinct names, are, first, those of Crete and Sparta, which are generally applauded; what is termed oligarchy comes next; this is not equally approved, and is a form of government which teems with evils.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Thirdly, democracy, which naturally follows oligarchy, although very different; and lastly comes tyranny, great and famous, which differs from them all, and is the fourth and worst disorder of a State.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Yes, we certainly hear of many curious forms of government which exist among them.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Do you know that governments vary as the dispositions of men vary, and that there must be as many of the one as there are of the other? For we cannot suppose that States are made of 'oak and rock,' and not out of the human natures which are in them.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Yes, the States are as the men are; they grow out of human characters.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Then if the constitutions of States are five, the dispositions of individual minds will also be five.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Certainly.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Then let us now proceed to describe the inferior sort of natures, being the contentious and ambitious, who answer to the Spartan polity; also the oligarchical, democratical, and tyrannical.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Let us place the most just by the side of the most unjust, and when we see them we shall be able to compare the relative happiness or unhappiness of him who leads a life of pure justice or pure injustice.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Certainly, we must do as you say.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: First, then, let us enquire how timocracy arises out of aristocracy. Clearly, all political changes originate in divisions of the actual governing power; a government which is united, however small, cannot be moved.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Very true.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: In what way, then, will our city be moved? Shall we, after the manner of Homer, pray the Muses to tell us 'how discord first arose'?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: The Muses would say: A city which is thus constituted can hardly be shaken; but, seeing that everything which has a beginning has also an end, even a constitution such as yours will not last for ever, but will in time be dissolved.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: And what do the Muses say next?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: When discord arose, then the two races were drawn different ways: the iron and brass fell to acquiring money and land and houses and gold and silver; but the gold and silver races, not wanting money but having the true riches in their own nature, inclined towards virtue and the ancient order of things.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: There was a battle between them, and at last they agreed to distribute their land and houses among individual owners; and they enslaved their friends and maintainers, whom they had formerly protected, and made of them subjects and servants.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: I believe that you have rightly conceived the origin of the change.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And the new government which thus arises will be of a form intermediate between oligarchy and aristocracy.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: In the honour given to rulers, in the abstinence of the warrior class from agriculture and trade, in the institution of common meals, and in the attention paid to gymnastics and military training—in all these respects this State will resemble the former.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: But in the fear of admitting philosophers to power, and in turning from them to passionate and less complex characters, who are by nature fitted for war rather than peace—this State will be peculiar.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Yes.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And men of this stamp will be covetous of money, like those who live in oligarchies; they will have a fierce secret longing after gold and silver, which they will hoard in dark places.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: That is most true.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And they are miserly because they have no means of openly acquiring the money which they prize; they will spend that which is another man's on the gratification of their desires, stealing their pleasures and running away like children from the law.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Undoubtedly, the form of government which you describe is a mixture of good and evil.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Why, there is a mixture; but one thing, and one thing only, is predominantly seen—the spirit of contention and ambition; and these are due to the prevalence of the passionate or spirited element.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Assuredly.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Now what man answers to this form of government—how did he come into being, and what is he like?

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: I think that in the spirit of contention which characterises him, he is not unlike our friend Glaucon.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Perhaps, but there are other respects in which he is very different. He should have more of self-assertion and be less cultivated, and yet a friend of culture; and he should be a good listener, but no speaker.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Such a person is apt to be rough with slaves, and he will also be courteous to freemen, and remarkably obedient to authority; he is a lover of power and a lover of honour.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Yes, that is the type of character which answers to timocracy.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Such an one will despise riches only when he is young; but as he gets older he will be more and more attracted to them, because he has a piece of the avaricious nature in him.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Who was his best guardian?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Philosophy, tempered with music, who comes and takes her abode in a man, and is the only saviour of his virtue throughout life.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Good.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Next, let us look at another man who is set over against another State; I believe that oligarchy follows next in order.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: And what manner of government do you term oligarchy?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: A government resting on a valuation of property, in which the rich have power and the poor man is deprived of it.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: I understand.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: The accumulation of gold in the treasury of private individuals is the ruin of timocracy; they invent illegal modes of expenditure; for what do they or their wives care about the law?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And then one, seeing another grow rich, seeks to rival him, and thus the great mass of the citizens become lovers of money.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Likely enough.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And so they grow richer and richer, and the more they think of making a fortune the less they think of virtue; for when riches and virtue are placed together in the scales of the balance, the one always rises as the other falls.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: True.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And what is honoured is cultivated, and that which has no honour is neglected. And so at last, instead of loving contention and glory, men become lovers of trade and money; they honour and look up to the rich man, and make a ruler of him, and dishonour the poor man.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: They do so.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: First of all, consider the nature of the qualification—just think what would happen if pilots were to be chosen according to their property, and a poor man were refused permission to steer, even though he were a better pilot?

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: You mean that they would shipwreck?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Yes; and is not this true of the government of anything?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Another discreditable feature is the inevitable division: such a State is not one, but two States, the one of poor, the other of rich men; and they are living on the same spot and always conspiring against one another.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: That, surely, is at least as bad.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Then oligarchy may now be dismissed. Let us next proceed to consider the nature and origin of the individual who answers to this State.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: A time arrives when the representative of timocracy has a son: at first he begins by emulating his father and walking in his footsteps, but presently he sees him foundering against the State as upon a sunken reef.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: He may have been a general or some other high officer who is brought to trial and either put to death, or exiled, or deprived of his privileges and all his property taken from him.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Nothing more likely.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And the son has seen and known all this—he is a ruined man, and his fear has taught him to knock ambition and passion from his bosom's throne; humbled by poverty he takes to money-making and by mean and miserly savings and hard work gets a fortune together.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Of all changes, there is none so speedy or so sure as the conversion of the ambitious youth into the avaricious one.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Then comes democracy; of this the origin and nature have still to be considered. And how does the change from oligarchy into democracy arise? Is it not on this wise—The good at which such a State aims is to become as rich as possible, a desire which is insatiable.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: What then?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: The rulers, being aware that their power rests upon their wealth, refuse to curtail by law the extravagance of the spendthrift youth because they gain by their ruin; they take interest from them and buy up their estates and thus increase their own wealth and importance.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And then democracy comes into being after the poor have conquered their opponents, slaughtering some and banishing some, while to the remainder they give an equal share of freedom and power; and this is the form of government in which the magistrates are commonly elected by lot.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Yes, that is the nature of democracy.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: In the first place, are they not free; and is not the city full of freedom and frankness—a man may say and do what he likes?

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: 'Tis said so.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And where freedom is, the individual is clearly able to order for himself his own life as he pleases?

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Clearly.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Then in this kind of State there will be the greatest variety of human natures?

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: There will.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: This, then, seems likely to be the fairest of States, being an embroidered robe which is spangled with every sort of flower. And just as women and children think a variety of colours to be of all things most charming, so there are many men to whom this State, which is spangled with the manners and characters of mankind, will appear to be the fairest of States.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Yes.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And is not their humanity to the condemned in some cases quite charming? Have you not observed how, in a democracy, many persons, although they have been sentenced to death or exile, just stay where they are and walk about the world—the gentleman parades like a hero, and nobody sees or cares?

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Yes, many and many a one.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: See too the forgiving spirit of democracy, and the 'don't care' about trifles, and the disregard which she shows of all the fine principles which we solemnly laid down at the foundation of the city.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Yes, she is of a noble spirit.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: These and other kindred characteristics are proper to democracy, which is a charming form of government, full of variety and disorder, and dispensing a sort of equality to equals and unequals alike.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: We know her well.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And last of all comes the most beautiful of all, tyranny, which out of democracy, tyranny naturally arises.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Clearly.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: The excessive increase of anything often causes a reaction in the opposite direction; and this is the case not only in the seasons and in vegetable and animal life, but above all in forms of government.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: True.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: The excess of liberty, whether in States or individuals, seems only to pass into excess of slavery.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Yes, the natural order.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And so tyranny naturally arises out of democracy, and the most aggravated form of tyranny and slavery out of the most extreme form of liberty.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: As we might expect.

modern.title: Book VIII: How Governments Fall Apart
modern.preview: Socrates: So Glaucon, we've established that in the perfect state, families and education are shared, and philosopher-warriors are kings.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: So Glaucon, we've established that in the perfect state, families and education are shared, and philosopher-warriors are kings.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: That's been agreed.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And the rulers will house soldiers in common quarters with no private property.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Right, they're warrior-athletes who only receive what they need to live—no ordinary possessions.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Good. Now let's get back to where we got sidetracked.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Easy enough. You said this state was good and the person who matches it is good. But if this is the true form, the others are false—and you mentioned four main false forms worth examining.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Your memory is excellent.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: I really want to hear about those four constitutions.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Here they are: First, the Spartan type—generally admired. Second, oligarchy—not as popular, full of problems. Third, democracy—naturally follows oligarchy but very different. Fourth and worst: tyranny.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Yeah, there are lots of weird government types out there.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Governments vary just like people do. States aren't made of rocks—they're made of human nature.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: True. States reflect the character of their people.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: So if there are five types of states, there are five types of individual personalities.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Makes sense.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Let's describe the inferior types: the competitive-ambitious type (Spartan), the oligarchic type, the democratic type, and the tyrannical type.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: We'll compare the most just person with the most unjust to see who's actually happier.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Let's do it.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: First: how does timocracy—government by honor—arise from aristocracy? All political change starts with division in the ruling class. A united government, even a small one, can't be overthrown.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Very true.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: How does our ideal city fall apart? Let's ask the Muses, Homer-style: 'How did discord first arise?'

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: The Muses would say: Even the best constitution won't last forever. Everything that begins must end.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: What happens next?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: When discord comes, the 'iron and bronze' types chase money, land, houses, gold, silver. But the 'gold and silver' types—naturally rich in virtue—lean toward the old ways.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: They fight, then compromise: divide up property, enslave the people they used to protect.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: That sounds right.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: The new government is a mix of oligarchy and aristocracy.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: It keeps some good things: honoring rulers, warriors avoiding business, common meals, athletic training.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: But it fears philosophers. It prefers passionate, simple warriors over complex thinkers.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Yeah.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: These people secretly crave money. They hoard gold and silver in hidden places.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: That's so true.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: They're cheap because they can't openly pursue wealth. They spend other people's money on pleasures, hiding from the law like children.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: This government is definitely a mix of good and bad.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: There's a mix, but one thing dominates: competition and ambition. That's the spirited element taking over.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Definitely.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: What kind of person matches this government?

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: The competitive spirit reminds me of Glaucon, actually.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Maybe in that one way. But this type is more aggressive, less educated—though they appreciate culture. They listen well but can't speak well.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: They're harsh to servants, polite to equals, and super obedient to authority. They love power and honor.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: That's the timocratic personality exactly.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Young, they despise money. But as they age, they want it more—there's greed hidden in them.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: What's their best protection?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Philosophy combined with culture. That's the only thing that can save virtue throughout life.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Good point.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Next up: oligarchy.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: What's oligarchy exactly?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Government based on wealth. Rich people have power, poor people don't.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Got it.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Here's how timocracy becomes oligarchy: People start hoarding private wealth. They find ways around the law—they and their spouses don't care about rules.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: One person sees another getting rich and wants to compete. Soon everyone's obsessed with money.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Probably.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: The richer they get, the less they care about virtue. When money and virtue are on a scale, one rises as the other falls.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: True.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Whatever's honored gets pursued; whatever's ignored gets neglected. So instead of valuing competition and glory, people value money and trade. They worship the rich and despise the poor.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: That's how it goes.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Think about this: what if ship captains were chosen by wealth, and a poor person couldn't steer even if they were the best navigator?

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: They'd crash the ship.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Exactly. Same with governing anything.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Another problem: oligarchy isn't one state—it's two. Rich versus poor, living together but constantly plotting against each other.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: That's just as bad.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Let's move on. How does the oligarchic individual develop?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Picture this: a timocratic father has a son who admires him at first. But then the father crashes—gets prosecuted, exiled, loses everything.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Happens all the time.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: The son sees this disaster. Fear kicks ambition off its throne. Humbled by poverty, he becomes obsessed with making money through hard work and penny-pinching.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Nothing transforms someone faster than watching their ambitious parent get destroyed.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Now democracy. How does it emerge from oligarchy? The oligarchy's whole goal is getting richer—an endless desire.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: And then?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: The rulers won't stop young spendthrifts from wasting money because they profit from it—they charge interest and buy up their property, getting even richer.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Eventually the poor overthrow the rich—killing some, exiling others—and give everyone equal power. Leaders are chosen by lottery.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: That's democracy.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: First thing you notice: freedom. Everyone can say and do whatever they want.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: That's what they say.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And where there's freedom, people can live however they choose.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Obviously.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: So you get the greatest variety of human types.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Definitely.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: It seems like the most beautiful state—like a colorful embroidered robe with every kind of pattern. Just as kids love bright colors, many people think this variety makes democracy the best state.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Yeah.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And it's so relaxed! People sentenced to death or exile just... walk around freely. Nobody notices or cares.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Seen it many times.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Democracy has this forgiving, 'whatever' attitude. It ignores all the careful principles we laid down for building a good state.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Very noble of her.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: So democracy is charming—full of variety and chaos, treating equals and unequals the same.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: We know her well.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And finally, the most 'beautiful' of all: tyranny. It grows naturally out of democracy.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Clearly.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Too much of anything causes a swing to the opposite. This is true in seasons, in living things, and especially in governments.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: True.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Extreme freedom leads to extreme slavery.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: That's the natural order.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: So tyranny naturally emerges from democracy. The worst slavery comes from the greatest freedom.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Makes sense.
